headline: Grandma's Chicken Noodle Soup
description: Grandma's recipe for chicken noodle soup is easy to make with leftover chicken and pantry staples. Everyone will enjoy a hot bowl of this savory soup.

video.description: See how to make a savory, 5-star chicken noodle soup.
video.name: Grandma’s Chicken Noodle Soup

name: Grandma's Chicken Noodle Soup

recipeInstructions.text: Bring a large pot of lightly salted water to a boil. Add egg noodles and oil, and boil until noodles are tender, about 8 minutes. Drain, rinse under cool running water, and drain again.
Bring broth, salt, and poultry seasoning to a boil in a Dutch oven. Stir in celery and onion; reduce the heat, cover, and simmer until vegetables have softened, about 15 minutes.
Mix cornstarch and water together in a small bowl until cornstarch is completely dissolved; gradually stir into soup. Stir in noodles and chicken, and cook until heated through, 2 to 3 minutes.

review.reviewBody: Best chicken noodle soup recipe I have ever found. The only change I made was to add carrots.

Delicious and easy recipe. I made a few personal preference edits to add more natural vitamins for a healthier soup and a bit more flavor.. I’m sure the recipe is excellent by itself though. Did not use butter or sauté the celery and onions hence cutting down on the fat. I also cooked the skinless boneless chicken breasts (you can use skinless chicken breast with bone) in the 12 cups of water using only 8 bullion cubes and cooked for 1 hour before adding the veggies and spices from Grandmas soup recipe, adding one ripe tomato, 1 potato with skin (in liu of cornstarch), 5 small whole garlic cloves and 1 small turnip cut in 3. I discard the Turnip at the end before adding the noodles, I used 6 ounces dried noodles to keep the soup more brothy. All veggie’s were finely diced (my preference for getting more of a mix of veggies and flavor in every spoonful. Totally cooking time was 2.5 hours, I finely diced the veggies while the chicken breast were cooking so the 2.5 hours included prep time and clean up once all ingredients were simmering together.

This is a great recipe and comes together in less than an hour. Measure your noodles carefully, too many will make the soup to thick. I added 1 cup of carrots and 2 cloves of garlic. I also recommend skinless boneless chicken thighs.
Such an easy recipe to follow and the whole family love it. Fabulous !!!
Why is the measurement for noodles in cups instead of ounces?
My family Loves this soup!! I reccomend it
I love doing things like my mamaw learned me how so I do all my cooking can't afford a restaurant food love new recipes ☺️

I like to cook the chicken in the broth with baby carrots, and the sautéed onions and celery. We don't do noodles, Husband makes dumplings and then adds them to the soup. While he's doing that, I'm deboning and shredding the now cooked chicken, to return to the pot.

I’m a salt lover, but I’ll cut back on the salt the next time I make this. I did add some carrots and black pepper, otherwise, followed the recipe. The poultry seasoning was a good addition, one I’d never before seen in chicken noodle soup, and the cornstarch slurry gave a nice consistency to the broth. We enjoyed along with a big salad for dinner.
This is an amazing recipe. I added a tablespoon of creamy chicken broth and a stick of butter for added flavor and a can of carrots. It was amazing.
This is simply an amazing, great recipe.

I have made this for years now, it never disappoints and is so easy. You can throw in whatever you want...carrots, onion, garlic, etc. I aso do half low sodium and regular broth. Always good on a cold night
Oh, this is good! Over the years I've tried many different recipes for chicken noodle soup but they always seem to be missing something. This one's about to be a staple in my house!❤️

Tried this because chicken noodle soup is my favorite. Didn't have any poultry spice so I used Italian seasoning. My only regret is downsizing the recipe to 4 servings because I wasn't sure we'd like it. We love it. It is a bit too salty for me , but everybody else thought it was fine.
I followed other suggestions re 1/2 low sodium chicken broth and adding an entire rotisserie chicken ~ this was delicious and perfect for a cold winter night.

LOOOVE this soup! This goes in our "make regularly" section of kitchen recipes. So tasty. I do add carrots, but I don't really change anything else usually. Thanks so much to whoever came up with this one.

I've been making chicken soup for 50 years but I have to say this recipe raised the bar big time! I made the following revisions;
* 1/2 chicken bone broth and 1/2 low sodium chicken broth (bone broth is very nutritious and I made a batch for a sick friend)
* I added 1 cup of finely chopped baby carrots and an additional 1/2 cup of onions
* I added 1 TBL of minced ginger and 2 TBL minced garlic
* 1/8 tsp cayenne
* I cooked bow tie noodles but stored them separately, I don't like soggy noodles and also wasn't sure if my friend's family had any gluten free people. I did use a rotisserie chicken, made it so easy. 
this is a hearty, savory soup. In the future I might add some fresh parsley for a garnish.
I added Badia complete seasoning. Also put a whole rotisserie chicken in. Came out awesome!
I messed up and put baking powder in instead of starch! It was by accident! The soup still tasted fantastic!

I used this recipe and made the best chicken noodle soup ever!
Made a couple changes….
Sautéed onions, celery and at least a cup of sliced carrots (have to have carrots!) in 1 tbsp or so of butter first
Added sage, thyme, 1 clove of garlic, pepper and cooked about 2 minutes
Added 2 boxes of low sodium chicken broth
Added 2 cups of water
Used grocery rotisserie chicken
Added the drippings and as much of the skin as possible
Brought to a boil and then removed skin
Added 1 cup of water mixed with cornstarch
Added wide egg noodles for 15 minutes

This will be my chicken noodle soup recipe from now on! Thank you!

This is an old fashioned chicken Boo Ya? recipe as we call it in Wisconsin?. The recipe is outstanding just as this is printed, kudos to the kitchen artist. Of course you can make adjustments and adaptations to your specific types of vegetables, salt levels and taste buds. Thank you so much for this amazing recipe?

I'd never made chicken soup before and wanted to give it a shot. This recipe was excellent! I did some of my own little variations the second and third times around. I can safely say that I've got this recipe committed to memory and am now confident in my ability to make this classic staple. Thanks for the recipe, original poster!
I made it almost exactly as written. I did omit the salt and cornstarch/water. I also added garlic, carrots and spinach. Delicious.
Very tasty! I didn't have enough chicken broth so I used some vegetable stock. I topped it off w/ fresh scallions. Yummy!
I made it, but I cut down the salt to 1 Tbsp. It was delicious. Thank you and I'm sure I'll make it again.
Turned out great! Family loved it! I used the rotisserie chicken and shredded it! Amazing!
Great flavor! Added rice instead of noodles but followed the remainder of the recipe. Great soup! Will make again & again. Thanks for sharing the recipe!

I was a little confused when I read the actual recipe. It doesn’t match the picture. The picture shows carrots in the soup and a pasta that is not egg noodles. With that said, I did use egg noodles, added carrots and used a rotisserie chicken. The soup turned out really well and it’s a new hit in our house!
Followed the recipe to a T, accept added carrots. Tasted phenomenal. Next time I will add more broth because I like my soup that way.
We used carrots instead of celery and onions.
Delicious and easy. The only modification was adding 1 cup of carrots, used half an onion and added a few bay leaves. Perfect for a chilly evening.

This recipe is perfect and easy. I used an oven roaster for the chicken (roasted in the microwave for 30 mins - seasoned with tons of salt, pepper, garlic, olive oil). I will only roast in the microwave with my Pampered Chef stoneware and it comes out crispy crispy brown and juicy. You could also buy a chicken roaster already cooked if you want to save time. The other change I made to the recipe was that I added carrots for flavor. Thank you for the basics for a perfect chicken noodle recipe. Oh and I also don't put the noodles in until ready to eat because if you add the noodles and then refrigerate leftovers the noodles soak up all of the liquid. I add noodles as we eat the soup.

I had leftover Thanksgiving turkey to use up, so I made this. 12 cups of broth will feed an army, so I scaled down to one carton of broth (just over 3 cups) and adjusted all the other ingredients. This is a nice base to really make the soup your own. I threw a can of black beans in with the veggies. will make again!

Very nice. I changed a few things to my liking. I added 1 cup of carrots and 2 bay leaves. I did not use any salt and I wanted my soup with a little more density. So, I added 1/2 c. of corn starch and 1/3 c. of water. I simmered the veggies for 20 minutes, not 15 because I wanted to make sure the carrots were cooked. Next time, I will not cook the egg noodles separately. I'll add them near the end.
I had to substitute wheat flour for the cornstarch but it came out fantastic all the same. I’ve been trying to replicate the home-cooked soup of my youth for years and here it is!

This recipe is not for the pictured soup. The photo of soup has Carrots and Pasta ,
None listed in the recipe. Nothing special.

This was very easy and very good. I did take the advice of others and added some fresh cracked pepper, basil, and a bay leaf with the poultry seasoning. I also put the rotisserie chicken in at the point where I went from boiling to simmering. I put an onion and carrot in at that time as well but also took those out when I removed the chicken as my kids prefer just broth, noodles, and chicken. It had a ton of flavor. Next time I think I may remove most of the skin from the rotisserie chicken.
Great! I added carrots and minced garlic. I skipped boiling the noodles separately; just throw them in the boiling broth and they’ll cook that way.

I liked this recipe!
And after reading a whole lot of the reviews and making some of my own changes...I love this recipe!
I have been known to double it...you should see how many Chicken Stock tetra packs I come home with...I am sure my husband thinks I am crazy!
First thing, I do not boil the noodles first...I put them in after I am satisfied with the flavour of the veggies, stock, chicken and spices. I toss them in and let everything simmer for a while together. Plus I add fresh coined carrots...the more veggies the fresher it feels and hearty! I used spices that I like along with what the recipe says. I will use Sodium-Reduced stock so I can add in salt and adjust as needed. I like to use my nose in the pantry and pick out savoury spices like Thyme, Dill Weed, Rosemary, a bit of Oregano, a bit of Basil, a bit of Garlic powder. Salt and Pepper of course. I say use what you like and if I am not happy with the balance, I will add a bit more stock, let it simmer longer and see how it feels then. And I loved loved loved the idea of using Grocery Store Rotisserie Chicken! Saved me time and money. I used thin latex gloves like you would for cutting Maraschino Cherries and split the chicken bits right down to the meat and throw those in...already cooked and seasoned! The soup freezes not too bad but not for too long. My kiddo likes it fresh but not frozen. Good luck with your soup!
Wonderful, wonderful soup! Oh my gosh, the whole family loved it and it was so easy to make. I'm keeping this on the short list. Thank you, Grandma!

I make this frequently. By storing 1-portion containers in the freezer (minus the noodles, which don't freeze well), I always have some on hand. When I pull 1 out of the freezer, I may or may not boil up some pasta to add.

My fiance and I love this soup. I halved the recipe. I used about 6 cups broth. I also used two chicken thighs. Trimmed off the skin and put it into the soup mixer with bone. I brought it to a boil than put it on medium low for about 20 to 25 mintues. Once chicken was cooked I took the thighs out cut them up took out bone and put the chicken back in. I added in the noodles to the soup so they can soak in the flavor. For seasoning I kept the poultry seasoning the same as the original recipe called for, added in Miss Dash Garlic and Herb, and fresh garlic. Next time I think I am also going to add fresh basil and a couple of bay leaves.
Excellent! I used stock and chicken bouillon and made the chicken breast right in stock. Didn't use a lot of salt but added some baby carrots. Loved it!
Excellent...no changes.
Wow a pot on wonderful feel good delight! Nothing better on a cold day. I used an entire rotisserie chicken and cooked the noodles in the broth. Yum!
Delicious recipe! I added juice of one lemon. I have made this several times One of the best Chicken Soup recipes that I have ever tasted!

I followed other reviewers' advice and put in a whole rotisserie chicken for about 15 minutes, then removed it, took off the meat then added it back into the pot. I also added carrots and two bay leaves. I used low-sodium broth, and it gave plenty of flavor without the extra salt. I also boiled the egg noodles separately and kept them separate from the soup, even later when storing leftovers in the fridge. When it's time to eat, just put a handful of noodles in the bowl and ladle the soup over top. I don't like how the noodles become so soggy and saturated when left in the pot, so we prefer adding the noodles to our own bowls right before eating. It was delicious and will definitely make again! Four stars as recipe is written, 5 stars with changes

I loved the recipe, I went out to my small winter garden and brought in Swiss chard, Curly kale,two very small kohlrabi, cut in small pieces, lots of carrots sliced, medium size, parsley, 3 stalks boc- choy,sliced smallish. I used ho made thick wonderful noodles, 3 green onions sliced plus 14 cup chopped yellow sweet onion. 2 bay leaves. I especially like thickening the broth with corn starch. I had 1/2 chicken breast that did not cook through last night, I cut it into cubes .and I wish I knew how to send a picture. Now I am looking for someone to feed.
Good but would have liked a little more flavor and some extra veggies (e.g. carrots, garlic, etc.). The proportion of solids to liquid seemed pretty good, though.
Followed recipe exactly except for 1/2 tsp of freshly ground pepper. So delicious!
I didn’t make any changes and it was delicious! My Mom loved it! The only thing I didn’t care for were the wide egg noodles
Tastes amazing! I used avocado oil instead of vegetable oil and used a bit more chicken and noodles - cuz that’s the best part.
Just made it very simple but very tasty 5
Great chicken noodle for sure. WAY too salty. Highly recommend using half low sodium broth. I also added carrots because that makes sense to me.

Excellent base recipe which you can add or delete items if you like. Poultry seasoning is a must! I added frozen peas and carrots to make it more hearty but left out the cornstarch and as I didn’t see a reason for it. I also left out the onion as we don’t prefer onion in our chicken soup. This is a keeper.
Added carrots, garlic, oregano, touch of hot sauce, and a bay leaf. Used rotisserie chicken and low sodium broth, cooked the noodles with the soup. Extra salt was not needed. 4.5 stars after changes.

Made this with many changes-I didn’t use oil, poultry seasoning or cornstarch. I purchased one 32 oz broth box, used it all and incorporated equal parts water. Followed the cooking instructions as listed with the omissions above and also used a rotisserie chicken vs cooking fresh chicken. The taste was spot on, not too salty, just right. I think I took the fuss out of it and my family loved it. These leftovers are delicious too.
Not bad but too salty. Will add less salt next time. I added water to it.

This is my go-to chicken noodle recipe. Sometimes I'll add in a dash of poultry seasoning for taste. I found that using low sodium chicken broth made it bland, so switched back to regular. So hearty and comforting!

Excellent, and so easy! Took the advice of other reviewers and used half low-sodium broth and didn’t add any additional salt. Put whole rotisserie chicken in with veggies and let simmer for 15 mins. Took it out and cut off chicken and put back into soup. Put raw noodles in last 15 minutes. So good! Next time I’ll add an extra can of broth as it came out very hearty, but could have used just a little more broth.

Excellent, and so easy! Took the advice of other reviewers and used half low-sodium broth and didn’t add any additional salt. Put whole rotisserie chicken in with veggies and let simmer for 15 mins. Took it out and cut off chicken and put back into soup. Put raw noodles in last 15 minutes. So good! Next time I’ll add an extra can of broth as it came out very hearty, but could have used just a little more broth.
I used my left over roast chicken. (I mean how many days can you eat it?) There were no changes and we found it delicious.

Made 8 cups with 5 cubes chicken stock. Added cubes potatoes (precooked), roasted chicken breasts with skin, pepper, cubed carrots, sliced celery, and sliced green onions. Used thin egg noodles, so they do not need to be precooked. No need to add additional salt. Delicious!

Added a little lemon juice and white pepper. 
Tastes great!
easy, tasty. would add carrots for color
Awesome awesome soup!

It was a very good recipe and tasted great. It is a bit salty so if you are sensitive to salt or need to keep salt to a minimum you could easily reduce the salt used.

I also used two stalks of celery and two carrots instead of one cup of just celery.
My family loved this! I used their favorite Kluski noodles and added carrots.

Soup was easy to make and tasty enough that my husband and I both loved it. I served this with seasoned crackers. I used chicken thighs. Dark meat seems to have a bit more flavor when making soup. I will make this again.
Amazing soup!!! This was easy to make and tastes so good! I used a rotisserie chicken from Kroger and put some carrots in with the celery and onion! Mmmmm good!

Wonderful recipe! I added some minced garlic, a bag of frozen crinkle cut carrots (no fresh on hand), and bay leaf. I did end up using a smidge more of the corn starch mixture to account for the water in the frozen carrots. Next time I will use advice from some reviewers and get a whole rotisserie chicken. As it was, I just sautéed some chicken cutlets in olive oil and diced. Makes a lot and your house will smell wonderful!
Great recipe
Good. Added Carrotts

This was tasty! Like others had said this is a great base for your creativity. Tune it to your preferences. I made this for my husband who was super sick and we both love chunky chunks of chicken so I cut up about 6 chicken breasts and browned those with a tiny bit of olive oil and barley seasoned it with Vegeta seasoning. (i don't really measure my spices, just eye ball it) Set that aside. I did make my noodles separate cause #1 I don't like the way it alters the taste of the soup #2 I didn't want it to soak up the organic chicken broth. Set that aside. Sauted a large onion, about 2 cups of celery and like 6 cloves of garlic in a tiny bit of olive oil. Set that aside. Then I brought the 12 cups of chicken broth and poultry seasoning to a boil, then added the sauted goodness and threw in some chopped up green onions and let it simmer til the celery was soft about 20 min. Then I threw in the chicken and noodles, along with some turmeric and a few pinches of salt and it came out pretty good. Once I had it in my bowl I put in some cayenne pepper to give it some kick and a little bit more salt and it was very tasty! Excited to make another batch and see how it turns out!
Perfect! Wonderful tasting. Added carrots and more corn starch slurry
As the recipe is written, this is WAY too salty. It tastes like the canned chicken noodle soup. I'm not giving a five star review AFTER the changes I made - just grading it on how it was written.

Outstanding! We used all organic ingredients, and chicken bone broth instead of regular broth. Only real change to recipe was to add some black pepper. Beats the pants off any chicken soup noodle soup I’ve had!
This was OK.
This is so good!!! I didn’t have onion so I used some onion powder. My husband said this was the best chicken noodle soup he’s ever had. And my kids love it.

This soup was delicious! Per some of the reviews, I used 2 32 oz cans of regular chicken broth and 1 32 oz can reduced sodium broth and it was salty enough. Also cooked the egg noodles separately in case I wanted to freeze the soup. I sautéed the onions and celery first in some garlic before adding to the broth and also added 1 cup diced carrots. For the chicken, I put in a whole rotisserie chicken in the broth for 15 min, removed, shredded and then added back into the soup. Such a nice flavor! Will definitely make again!

On flavor I’d give this a 3, but liked how quick and easy this was. Good ideas to use low-sodium broth as oftentimes chicken soup can be extremely salty. Definitely add the carrots and some additional seasoning, otherwise it’s a bit bland

Like anyone, I made some changes. I added fresh mushrooms, chopped carrots and chopped potatoes. Then I added minced garlic, Italian seasoning and a dash of Red pepper flakes because I can.
 For the chicken I used a whole Rotisserie chicken in pieces. About 4 cups.
Again I wish All Recipes would use the right picture. They put their own in many times.
Nothing like grandma's chicken noodle soup on a cold winter day. Now I'm making these memories for my grandchildren. very good recipe

- used shredded rotisserie chicken from the store
- almost doubled the poultry seasoning
- no added salt
- put the uncooked noodles in the soup for the last 15 min. of cooking. I added a cup more noodles (I like lots of noodles)
- sautéed carrots, celery, and onion in 3 tbsp of butter and chopped garlic before adding broth.
- added fresh chopped basil
I added carrots

LOVED it!!! My changes were only because I didn't want to run to the store at last minute because we have a sick one home. I did a full package of organic chicken broth (not 12 cups), 1/2 onion, 2 carrots, 2 celery, no poultry seasoning, approx tablespoon of corn starch in a little water to dissolve and rinsed off 3/4 C. of dry Orzo pasta, placed in broth mix, brought to boil, then let it simmer for the remaining 15-20 minutes until orzo was just soft enough. That was just enough for 2 big bowls of soup.

I substituted with potato starch, and added cut up pork strips and a carrot. I also have gluten free pasta, so I cooked a cup separately and poured the soup on top.
It's exquisite. You could definitely can eat this several times without becoming fed up.
Easy to make and totally great tasting soup. I added some shredded carrots.
Clearly the photo does not belong to the recipe. I added equal amount of cubed carrots as celery is called for as well.

This was delicious!!! Definitely my go to from now on. The only things I changed was that I used the homestyle egg noodles from the frozen section (I have always loved Bob Evans chicken noodle soup, and they use the same type of noodles and I just can’t compromise with using any other kind) and I added a cup of diced carrots with the celery and onion. My picky 2 year old will lick the bowl clean when I make this, which is always a win!!

I had to make a few changes bc of what I had on hand. I didn’t have poultry seasoning so I used seasoned salt instead. I also only used 8c of broth instead of 12c, so it’s a thicker soup. I did not add any additional salt! An extra tablespoon and a half is crazy in my opinion (why I gave it 4 stars - that nasty). But if you like salt then make the soup and add whatever amount you want at the end if it needs it. I also used chicken thighs instead of breasts.

So good! I boiled about 3 lbs bone-in thighs for 40 minutes (seasoned with poultry seasoning, garlic, and salt). Reserved the (strained) broth, chopped the chicken. I used 2cups chopped celery (including leaves), 1 c carrots, 1 c onions. Added 2 bullion cubes (I

Followed other reviewers' advice and added a whole rotisserie chicken. It was good, but could have used a bit more cooking time. Also, I used reduced sodium chicken broth and left out salt, but ended up adding a bit of salt at the end. Overall, this was a very good soup, although I would have liked more broth.

I read the previous reviews and incorporated many of those suggestions, especially adding the rotisserie chicken, low-sodium broth, garlic and carrots. It was yummy! I liked it a lot and it took much less time than the previous recipe I've been using. My toddler lapped it up as well! This will be my go-to recipe moving forward. I rated it 4 because I do think the suggestions from other reviews made a big difference. I'm not sure if it would have been as savory without those additions. Thanks to the original author and everyone else for sharing this!
added 2 teaspoons of better than bouillon chicken since my broth lacked a little flavor.
I used low sodium broth and it was still way too salty.

A note about cooking noodles in the actual soup pot or separately. I recommend doing separately, for these reasons : 1) soup is cooked to a level of it being hot -not boiling, noodles you would boil to eldente.. The soup should not be boiled. 2) when you boil the noodles you will see the cloudiness in the water, that is starch, you really don’t want that in your soup, you should thicken your soup with other methods 3)If that starch/cloudy water is in your soup it changes the color and flavor of soup 4) The noodles will absorb your soup broth/liquid if cooked in the soup, yes you can add more liquid but this depletes the recipe/intended flavor 5)Noodles are more apt to get mushy when cooked in the soup and the soup have Less broth

Delicious!! Followed the other reviews! Added bay leaves, basil, only 1 tsp salt, 1 1/2 cup carrots, added more rotisserie chicken (we like it hearty) and just cooked the noodles in the soup. May try adding garlic next time. Kids gobbled it up

Made this tonight for my sick husband and son. Sadly, this recipe was very bland. They both commented that it had no taste, so I had a bowl myself and have to agree. Extremely bland and needs a lot more seasonings. I’ll keep looking for a good chicken noodle soup recipe.
